message: I'm a long term PHP developer but moved to Python and some Ruby in the recent years and now when I have to code something in PHP I really miss the great ecosystem around Ruby's Sinatra or Python's Flask... been there too?
Zend Framework or Symfony are for sure fully viable alternatives but many PHP projects would really benefit from a ecosystem of small framework-agnostic reusable pieces...
PHP Slim is a Sinatra inspired micro-framework for quickly generating restful apis (http://thechangelog.com/post/1159626415/slim-a-php5-sinatra-clone)
I use gluephp and h2o-template. not sure about the orm
I've build my own but the routing sucks :)
When it comes to ORM you could go with Idiorm or Paris (which is a ActiveRecord implementation of Idiorm): http://j4mie.github.com/idiormandparis/
you can try olso silex or also lithium 3

Silex (http://silex-project.org/) is inspired by Sinatra and built with Symfony2 (http://symfony.com/) components. It's a really nice piece of software, with great documentations and quite a few extensions for quickly adding functionality to your project.

I strongly believe that the best Sinatra-like PHP framework is a new framework called Laravel. Also, it's in active development. Here is a link to the Home page: http://laravel.com/ . And here is a link to the Github repository: https://github.com/taylorotwell/laravel

"The best" implies comparison - have you run any other than Laravel? I gave it a quick glance and it looks like a bunch of static methods, all tightly coupled with each other. This is probably why I see no testing, unit or function wise, nor any interface for third party extensions. It's probably a nice contained system but I would never base a project on such a silo of code.
